title: Armand Huyghé
text:
Armand Christophe Huyghé (11 July 1871 – 2 March 1944), later knighted Armand Huyghé de Mahenge, was a <a href="Belgium">Belgian</a> career soldier. He is best known for his service in the <a href="Belgian%20Congo">Belgian Congo</a> during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, where he succeeded <a href="Charles%20Tombeur">Charles Tombeur</a> as commander of the Belgian forces in the <a href="East%20African%20Campaign%20%28World%20War%20I%29">East African Campaign</a> in 1917. He commanded the Belgian contingent during the <a href="Occupation%20of%20the%20Rhineland">Allied occupation of the Rhineland</a> after the war. During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, he was involved in the <a href="Belgian%20resistance">resistance</a> and, after being captured by the Germans, was deported to <a href="Buchenwald%20concentration%20camp">Buchenwald concentration camp</a> where he died in 1944.
Biography.
Huyghé, born in <a href="Leuven">Leuven</a>, studied at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%20%28Belgium%29">Royal Military Academy</a> and entered the Belgian Army in 1891, serving in the <a href="8th%20Regiment%20of%20the%20Line">8th Regiment of the Line</a>, as a junior officer. In 1893, he transferred to the "<a href="Force%20Publique">Force Publique</a>", the colonial militia, in the then-<a href="Congo%20Free%20State">Congo Free State</a> which at the time was under the direct personal control of <a href="Leopold%20II%20of%20Belgium">King Leopold II</a> but returned to Belgium soon after, suffering from illness.
At the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Huyghé served in the Belgian Army during the <a href="German%20invasion%20of%20Belgium%20%281914%29">German invasion of Belgium</a>, fighting at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Li%C3%A8ge">Battles of Liège</a>, <a href="Siege%20of%20Antwerp%20%281914%29">Antwerp</a> and <a href="Battle%20of%20the%20Yser">the Yser</a> in 1914. In 1915, with the front <a href="Yser%20Front">stabilised at the Yser</a>, Huyghé returned to the <a href="Belgian%20Congo">Belgian Congo</a> to serve in the "Force Publique" in the <a href="East%20African%20Campaign%20%28World%20War%20I%29">East African Campaign</a>. He initially served under Colonel Molitor in the North Brigade ("Brigade Nord") during the operations on the frontier of German <a href="Ruanda-Urundi">Ruanda-Urundi</a> and fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Tabora">Battle of Tabora</a> in 1916. Replacing <a href="Charles%20Tombeur">Charles Tombeur</a> as commander of the "Force Publique" on campaign in February 1917, he commanded the Belgian forces at the important <a href="Battle%20of%20Mahenge">Battle of Mahenge</a> in October 1917.
Returning to Belgium after the war, he commanded the Belgian army of occupation during the <a href="Occupation%20of%20the%20Rhineland">Allied occupation of the Rhineland</a>. Retired for ill-health, he held a number of official positions in Belgian companies in the Congo after 1929 on the boards of the <a href="Compagnie%20du%20chemin%20de%20fer%20du%20Bas-Congo%20au%20Katanga">Compagnie du chemin de fer du Bas-Congo au Katanga</a> (BCK), <a href="Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9%20des%20mines%20d%27%C3%A9tain%20du%20Ruanda-Urundi">Société des mines d'étain du Ruanda-Urundi</a> and the <a href="Compagnie%20des%20grands%20%C3%A9levages%20congolais">Compagnie des grands élevages congolais</a>. In 1933, he was made a "chevalier" (<a href="knight%23Honorific%20orders%20of%20knighthood">knight</a>) by <a href="Albert%20I%20of%20Belgium">King Albert I</a> in recognition of his role during World War I.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Huyghé was involved in the <a href="Belgian%20Resistance">resistance</a> to the <a href="German%20occupation%20of%20Belgium%20during%20World%20War%20II">German occupation</a> and was arrested in 1943. He was detained at <a href="Buchenwald%20concentration%20camp">Buchenwald concentration camp</a>, together with former prime minister <a href="Paul-%C3%89mile%20Janson">Paul-Émile Janson</a>, where he died of disease in 1944.
